intro: Pteracanthus hygrophiloides, commonly known as the water-loving clubmoss, is a species of primitive plant belonging to the family Lycopodiaceae. It is characterized by its small, scale-like leaves and a creeping rhizome system that allows it to thrive in moist, shaded environments. This plant typically grows in wetlands, stream banks, and other areas with high humidity and poor drainage. Its reproductive structures include microsporangia and megasporangia, which are borne on specialized stalks. Pteracanthus hygrophiloides plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various microorganisms and invertebrates.
